lexUnit.name: clear.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to remove unwanted objects or obstructions from a surface

sentence.text: Hargreave cleared a pile of newspapers from a chair and seated himself at the table .
One Midlands wine wholesaler was ordered to clear dust from a warehouse floor used only for cased goods , the association said .
He tried to clear the grit from his voice and swallowed his words along with it .
The UK government has announced a ban on the non-agricultural use of the pesticides atrazine and simizine , commonly used to clear weeds from roadside verges , railway lines and footpaths .
Now , when I was a prisoner of the French ( and , yes , that 's another story ) I had to clear corpses from the battle field .
They worked together efficiently in the spotless kitchen and beamed satisfaction when they cleared four empty plates from the table .
Ellen meanwhile cleared the foam from the teak deck , then searched Wavebreaker 's cabins .
She stood up and began clearing the dishes away from the table , dumping them in the sink and then hurriedly washing them in some soapy water .
Myself and another Englishman called Ronny were given rakes and told to clear the leaves off a huge area of gravel .
She cleared these things to one side and laid the cigar down in the middle of the dressing-table .
Sometimes they cleared all the furniture back against the walls so that they could practise their special dance routines , or held rowdy parties in each other 's rooms .
Its three walls were built out of stones cleared from the surrounding cultivated fields .
The oesophagus also receives mucus cleared from the lungs by the ciliary mechanism or by coughing which is also swallowed .
She and the other staff take a break -- chef usually prepares them something -- then they work through , clearing away and washing up until 11.00-11.30pm .
The maid had cleared away , and now she came out with a jug of wine and two glasses .
